sfr module

Galaxy parameter distributions.

class sfr.BoogaardSFMR(redshift: float)

Bases: object

Redshift-dependent SFMR with no flattening at high masses.

Computes the redshift-dependent star formation-mass relation (SFMR) with no flattening at high masses, for a given redshift. Allows calculating either the star-formation rate (SFR) from the galaxy stellar mass, or the galaxy stellar mass from the SFR. Meant to be implemented trough sfr.SFMR().

Parameters:

redshift (float) – Redshift at which to compute the relation.

redshift

Redshift at which to compute the relation.

Type:

float

sfr(logm)

Compute the SFR for a given galactic stellar mass log10(m).

logm(sfr)

Compute the galactic stellar mass log10(m) for a given SFR.

Notes

The model is by Boogaard et al. (2018) [1] , with the SFR as a log-linear function of the mass, a the slope and b the intercept.

See also

SFMR

Implements this class.

References

[1] (1,2)

Boogaard,L. A., Brinchmann, J., Bouche, N. et al. (2018). The MUSE Hubble Ultra Deep Field Survey - XI. Constraining the low-mass end of the stellar mass-star formation rate relation at z<1. A&A, 619, A27. doi:10.1051/0004-6361/201833136

A = 0.83

Slope of the log-linear SFR(m).

Type:

float

property b: float

Log-linear SFR(m) intercept. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

property c: float

SFMR auxiliary variable. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

class sfr.SpeagleSFMR(redshift: float)

Bases: object

Redshift-dependent SFMR with moderate flattening at high masses.

Computes the redshift-dependent star formation-mass relation (SFMR) with moderate flattening at high masses, while keeping a BoogaardSFMR at low masses, for a given redshift. Allows calculating the star-formation rate (SFR) from the galaxy stellar mass. Meant to be implemented trough sfr.SFMR().

Parameters:

redshift (float) – Redshift at which to compute the relation.

redshift

Redshift at which to compute the relation.

Type:

float

lowmass_sfmr

SFMR below LOGM_BREAK.

Type:

sfr.BoogaardSFMR.

sfr(logm)

Computes the SFR for a given galactic stellar mass log.

logm(sfr)

Computes the galactic stellar mass log for a given SFR.

Notes

The SFR is modeled as a log-linear function of the mass, with a as the slope and b the intercept. Below a break mass :const:LOGM_BREAK, the SFMR is given by a BoogaardSFMR (Boogaard et al., 2018) [1]. Above the break, the log-linear form is kept, but the slope becomes redshift-dependent, following the model by Speagle et al. (2014) [2]. The intercept is defined by continuity with the Boogaard SFMR.

References

[2]

Speagle, J. S., Steinhardt, C. L., Capak, P. L., Silverman, J. D. (2014). A highly consistent framework for the evolution of the star-forming “main sequence” from z~0-6. ApJS, 214, 15. doi:10.1088/0067-0049/214/2/15.

LOGM_BREAK = 9.7

Break mass between Boogaard and Speagle SFMRs.

Type:

float

property time: float

Age of the universe, in Gyr, at redshift.

Type:

float

property a: float

Log-linear SFR(m) slope. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

property b: float

Log-linear SFR(m) intercept. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

class sfr.TomczakSFMR(redshift: float)

Bases: object

Redshift-dependent SFMR with sharp flattening at high masses.

Computes the redshift-dependent star formation-mass relation (SFMR) with sharp flattening at high masses, while keeping a BoogaardSFMR at low masses, for a given redshift. Allows calculating the star-formation rate (SFR) from the galaxy stellar mass. Meant to be implemented trough sfr.SFMR().

Parameters:

redshift (float) – Redshift at which to compute the relation.

redshift

Redshift at which to compute the relation.

Type:

float

lowmass_sfmr

SFMR below logm_break.

Type:

sfr.BoogaardSFMR

sfr(logm)

Computes the SFR for a given galactic stellar mass log10(m).

Notes

Tomczak et al. (2016) [3] model the SFMR as a power-law with slope GAMMA at low masses, which saturates to s0 above a turn-off mass m_to. Following Chruslinska & Nelemans (2019) [4], here the SFMR is given as a sfr.BoogaardSFMR below the turn-off, and by the Tomczak SFMR above it.

References

[3]

Tomczak, A. R., Quadri, R. F., Tran, K.-V. H. et al. (2014). Galaxy stellar mass functions from ZFOURGE/CANDELS: an excess of low-mass galaxies since z=2 and the rapid buildup of quiescent galaxies. ApJ, 783, 95. doi:10.1088/0004-637X/783/2/85

GAMMA = 1.091

Power-law slope.

Type:

float

property s0: float

High mass saturation SFR log. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

property logm_to: float

Turn-off mass log. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

property logm_break: float

Break mass between Boogaard and Tomczak SFMRs.

Type:

float

property break_corr: float

Correction to match the SFMR models at the break.

Type:

float

class sfr.SFMR(redshift: float, flattening: str = 'none', scatter: str = 'none')

Bases: object

General SFMR, with either no, moderate or sharp flattening at high masses.

General SFMR class, with options for no, moderate or sharp flattening at high masses. Provides a unified way to access the three SFMR classes: BoogaardSFMR (no flattening), SpeagleSFMR (moderate flattening) and TomczakSFMR (sharp flattening).

Parameters:

  • redshift (float) – Redshift at which to compute the relation.

  • flattening ({'none', 'moderate', 'sharp'}, default: 'none') – SFMR model flattening option.

redshift

Redshift at which to compute the relation.

Type:

float

flattening

SFMR model flattening option.

Type:

str

sfmr

An instance of the BoogaardSFMR, SpeagleSFMR or Tomczak SFMR class, depending on the flattening option.

Type:

class instance

property sfmr

Instance of one of the SFMR model classes.

property scatter
sfr(logm)
class sfr.MZR(redshift, mzr_model='KK04', logm_min=7.0, logm_max=12.0, scatter='none')

Bases: object

Redshift-dependent mass-(gas) metallicity relation for one of four parameter sets.

Compute the redshift-dependent mass-(gas) metallicity relation (MZR) for one of four parameter sets: : ‘KK04’, ‘T04’, ‘M09’ or ‘PP04’. The MZR takes the form of a power law at low masses with slope gamma, which flattens around a turnover mass m_to to an asymptotic metallicity z_a. Metallicity given as Z_OH=12+log10(O/H).

Parameters:

  • redshift (float) – Redshift at which to compute the relation.

  • mzr_model ({'KK04', 'T04', 'M09', 'PP04'}, default: 'KK04') – Option of MZR parameter set.

  • logm_min (float, default: 7.0) – Log10 of the minimum stellar galaxy mass in the relation.

  • logm_max (float, default: 12.0) – Log10 of the maximum stellar galaxy mass in the relation.

  • scatter ({'none', 'normal', 'max', 'min'}, default : 'none') – Scatter model option.

ip_param_array
redshift

Redshift at which to compute the relation.

Type:

float

mzr_model

Option of MZR parameter set.

Type:

str

logm_min

Log10 of the minimum stellar galaxy mass in the relation.

Type:

float

logm_max

Log10 of the maximum stellar galaxy mass in the relation.

Type:

float

z_a

Asymptotic Z_OH metallicity of the high-mass end of the relation. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

logm_to

Turnover mass, i.e., mass at which the relation begins to flatten to the asymptotic z_a.

Type:

float

gamma

Low-mass end slope. Redshift-dependent.

Type:

float

dz

Normalization variation rate with redshift between z=2.2 and z=3.5.

Type:

float

_ip_redshift_array

Array of redshifts from which to interpolate.

Type:

numpy array

_ip_arrays_len

Length of mass array to use for interpolation.

Type:

int

set_params()

Interpolate from the original parameter set to the given redshift.

zoh(logm)

Compute metallicity for a given galactic stellar mass log10(m).

logm(zoh)

Compute the galactic stellar mass log10(m) for a given metallicity.

Warns:

UserWarning – If methods zoh(m) or m(zoh) are run before set_params().

Notes

Four sets of parameters for this same relation form are made available, in following the models collected by Chruslinska & Nelemans (2019) [4]: Tremontini et al. (2004) [5] (T04), Kobulnicky & Kewley [6] (2004) (KK04), Pettini & Pagel [7] (2004) (PP04) and Mannucci et al. [8] (2009) (M09).

The relation is fitted for four redshift bins z ~ 0.07, 0.7, 2.2, 3.5, such that each model provides four sets of corresponding MZR parameters. In order to get the MZR at any other redshift, a (mass, metallicity) array is generated at each of the four original z and, for each mass, the metallicity is interpolated to the desired z. Fitting of the MZR to the interpolated points sets the parameters at that z.

For z > 3.5, parameters are kept as for z=3.5, but it is assumed that the normalization varies linearly with redshift with the same rate as the average rate (dz) between z=2.2 and z=3.5.

References

[4] (1,2)

Chruslinska, M. & Nelemans, G. (2019). Metallicity of stars formed throughout the cosmic history based on the observational properties of star-forming galaxies. MNRAS, 488(4), 5300. doi:10.1093/mnras/stz2057

[5]

Tremontini, C. A., Heckamn, T. M., Kauffmann, G. et al. (2004). The Origin of the Mass-Metallicity Relation: Insights from 53,000 Star-forming Galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. ApJ, 613, 898. doi:10.1086/423264

[6]

Kobulnicky, H. A., Kewley, L. J. (2004). Metallicities of 0.3 < z < 1.0 Galaxies in the GOODS-North Field. ApJ, 617, 240. doi:10.1086/425299

[7]

Pettini, M., Pagel, B. E. J. (2004). [Oiii]/[Nii] as an abundance indicator at high redshift. MNRAS, 348(3), L59. doi:10.1111/j.1365-2966.2004.07591.x

[8]

Mannucci, F., Cresci, G., Maiolino, R. et al. (2009). LSD: Lyman-break galaxies Stellar populations and Dynamics - I. Mass, metallicity and gas at z~3.1. MNRAS, 398(4), 1915. doi:10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15185.x

property scatter
property ip_param_array

Array of MZR parameters from the chosen model.

set_params()

Interpolate from the original parameter set to the given redshift.

Notes

The relation is fitted for four redshift bins z ~ 0.07, 0.7, 2.2, 3.5, such that each model provides four sets of corresponding MZR parameters. In order to get the MZR at any other redshift, a (mass, metallicity) array is generated at each of the four original z and, for each mass, the metallicity is interpolated to the desired z. Fitting of the MZR to the interpolated points sets the parameters at that z.

For z > 3.5, parameters are kept as for z=3.5, but it is assumed that the normalization varies linearly with redshift with the same rate as the average rate (dz) between z=2.2 and z=3.5.

logm(zoh: float) → float

Compute the metallicity, Z_OH=12+log10(O/H), from the log10 galactic stellar mass.

zoh(logm: float) → float

Compute the log10 galactic stellar mass from the metallicity, Z_OH=12+log10(O/H).

class sfr.Corrections(metallicity, sfr)

Bases: object

Corrections to a Kroupa initial mass function-based star formation rate distribution.

Calculates the appropriate corrections to the star formation rate (SFR) obtained when the Kroupa universal initial mass function (PowerLawIMF), or simply Kroupa SFR, is assumed, for the environment-dependent galactic PowerLawIMF (gIMF) obtained in the integrated galaxy-wide PowerLawIMF (IGIMF) framework. The corrections are a multiplicative factor dependent on the Kroupa SFR value and the metallicity, [Fe/H].

data_path

Path to the precalculated correction grid file.

Type:

pathlib Path

metallicity

Array of metallicities at which to compute the corrections.

Type:

numpy array

sfr_kroupa
Array of Kroupa SFR values correspondent to each metallicity for

which to compute corrections.

Type:

numpy array

corrections

Array of calculated corrections for the given SFR-metallicity pairs.

Type:

numpy array

metallicity_data

Metallicity column from the precalculated grid.

Type:

numpy array

sfr_kroupa_data

Kroupa SFR column from the precalculated grid.

Type:

numpy array

sfr_correction_data

Correction columns from the precalculated grid.

Type:

numpy array

get_corrections()
Interpolates from the precalculated correction grid to the given

metallicity-Kroupa SFR pairs.

Notes

The corrections are obtained for arbitrary values of SFR and metallicity by interpolation of the SFR density grid from Chruslinska et al. (2020) [9], kindly made available in full by Martyna Chruslinska.

All metallicities are given as [Fe/H].

References

[9] (1,2)

Chruslinska, M., Jerabkova, T., Nelemans, G., Yan, Z. (2020). The effect of the environment-dependent PowerLawIMF on the formation and metallicities of stars over cosmic history. A&A, 636, A10. doi:10.1051/0004-6361/202037688

load_data()

Load original correction data into the appropriate arrays.

get_corrections()

Compute corrections for the grid of metallicities and Kroupa SFR values provided.

class sfr.ChruslinskaSFRD(model='midmet', canon=False, per_redshift_met_bin=False)

Bases: object

Star formation rate density grid.

Loads the precomputed star formation rate density (SFRD) grid over redshift (z) and metallicity (Z_OH) and finds the SFRD corresponding to the (z,Z) pair closest to the (z,Z) provided by the user. Allows for choosing between the extreme low- and high-metallicity models, or a moderate-metallicity model.

MODEL_PATH_DICT

Dictionary containing the paths to the precomputed SFRD grids.

Type:

dict

SFRD_ZOH_ARRAY

Array of Z_OH metallicity values making up one axis of the SFRD grids.

Type:

numpy array

SFRD_Z_ARRAY

Array of Z metallicity values making up one axis of the SFRD grid.

Type:

numpy array

model

Choice of SFRD grid model.

Type:

str

sfrd_redshift_array

Array of redshifts making up the other axis of the SFRD grid.

Type:

numpy array

sfrd_dtime_array

Array of time steps defining the SFRD grid redshifts.

Type:

numpy array

logsfrd_array

Log10(SFRD) array over the redshift-metallicity grid.

Type:

numpy array

load_grid()

Loads the SFRD grid from disk.

get_logsfrd(feh, redshift)

Returns the log10(SFRD) corresponding to the pair in the grid closest to the given (feh, redshift).

Warns:

UserWarning – If get_logsfrd(feh, redshift) is run before set_grid().

Notes

The precomputed SFRD grids are by Chruslinska et al. (2020) [9] and were calculated with the same GSMF, SFMR and MZR relations employed in this module. Different combinations of the different relation options lead to the three grid options, differentiated by the degree to which the SFR distribution is shifted towards higher or lower metallicities. These grids already take into account the corrections for environment-dependent PowerLawIMF treated in the Corrections class.

MODEL_PATH_DICT = {'highmet': PosixPath('/home/lucasmdesa/Documents/GitHub/environIMF/data/C20_Results/SFRD_Z_z_data/302w14vIMF3aeh_FOH_z_dM.dat'), 'lowmet': PosixPath('/home/lucasmdesa/Documents/GitHub/environIMF/data/C20_Results/SFRD_Z_z_data/204w14vIMF3aeh_FOH_z_dM.dat'), 'midmet': PosixPath('/home/lucasmdesa/Documents/GitHub/environIMF/data/C20_Results/SFRD_Z_z_data/103w14vIMF3aeh_FOH_z_dM.dat')}

set_grid()

Build redshift and SFRD arrays corresponding to the grid from the data files.

get_logsfrd(feh, redshift)

For a given [Fe/H],redshift pair, find the log10(SFRD) corresponding to the closest pair in the grid.

Parameters:

  • feh (float) – The desired [Fe/H].

  • redshift (float) – The desired redshift.

Returns:

logsfrd – Log10(SFRD) corresponding to the pair in the grid closest to the given feh,redshift.

Return type:

float

Warns:

UserWarning – If the SFRD grid has not been loaded yet (load_grid() not run).

Warning

The user should bear in mind the grids range from -4 to 1.7 in metallicity and 0 to 10 in redshift. Passing values outside these ranges will always return the edges of the grid.
